Core::DatabaseDocumentation.html_documentation: Contains a short hint of what the parameter controls.
When set to true, the parameters takes a list of values.
This table stores descriptions of the parameters for an Core::AlgorithmImplementation.
Column name that is being documented. If this is null, then the documentation applies to the table.
Primary key
Documentation for the "attribute_name" describing the intended use of the attribute. This documentation can be written using HTML tags.

Stores documentation describing the intended use of tables and attributes in the GUS schema

FK to SRes.OntologyTerm to indicate the anatomical structure associated with the model context. May be nullable.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm to indicate the bioloical process associated with the model context. May be nullable.
A detailed textual description of the model context, may be used for display in model visualizations.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm that along with developmental_stage_start_id indicates a developmental time span associated with the model context. May be nullable.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm that along with developmental_stage_end_id indicates a developmental time span associated with the model context. May be nullable.
The context name, may be used for display in model visualizations.
This table stores the biological context in which a model is valid. This includes one or more of the following: anatomical structure, biological process, or developmental stage.
A detailed textual description of the network, may be used for display in model visualizations.
The name of the network; may be used for display in visualizations.
This table stores information (name and description) about networks, or lists of related or connected relationships.
Display label for the network node in a visualization.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm to indicate the type of network node, e.g., gene, protein, small molecule, complex, etc.

When the value of a network node corresponds to an entry in this database, this points to the entry in the relevant table. For example, if the network node is a gene, this can point to the entry in DoTS.Gene corresponding to that gene.

When the value of a network node corresponds to an entry in this database, this points to the table (FK to Core.TableInfo) storing that entry. For example, if the network node is a gene, this can point to the DoTS.Gene table.

This table stores information about nodes, or connection points between edges in a network visualization, in a network. Different attributes corresponding to different network node types can be associated with a node by pointing to an entry in the database with the soft key (table_id, row_id).
FK to Model.ModelContext pointing to biological context for which the relationship is valid.
FK to Model.NetworkRelationship pointing to the abstraction of the relationship.
FK to Model.NetworkRelationshipType pointing to the type of the network relationship.

When the relationship is directed (i.e., a source and target node can be specified), this attribute should be assigned a value of 1 (node pointed to by Model.NetworkRelationship node_id is the source) or 2 (node pointed to by Model.NetworkRelationship associated_node_id is the source). When the relationship is undirected, this attribute should be NULL.
When applicable, a weight or confidence associated with a particular instance (defined by context, type, and directionality) of a network relationship.

This table stores specific instances of abstract relationships defined in Model.NetworkRelationship. An instance links a relationship to a relationship type and a model context and indicates the directionality of the relationship, when relevant.
This table links specific instances of network relationships (stored in Model.NetworkRelContext) to networks (stored in Model.Network).

FK to SRes.OntologyTerm that points to a descriptive categorization of the type of evidence for visualization purposes. One category may be associated with multiple evidence codes (pointed to by the evidence_code_id).
Descriptive text that summarizes the evidence for display in visualizations of the associated relationship instance.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm that points to the formal evidence code identifying the type of evidence supporting the relationship instance.

When the source of the evidence corresponds to an entry in the this database, this points to the entry in the relevant table. For example, if the evidence is a traceable author statement, this would point to the entry in SRes.BibliographicReference corresponding to the relevant publication. If the evidence is the result of an analysis, this would point to the entry in Study.ProtocolAppNode corresponding to the analysis.

When the source of the evidence corresponds to an entry in the this database, this points to the table (FK to Core.TableInfo) storing that entry. For example, if the evidence is a traceable author statement, this would point to the SRes.BibliographicReference table. Alternatively, if the evidence is the result of an analysis, this would point to the Study.ProtocolAppNode table.
When applicable, a fdr associated with this evidence. This may be a value stored elsewhere in the Results schema in this database.

When applicable, a specific genomic location (in the form chr:start-stop:strand or taxon_chr:start-stop:strand) associated with the relationship instance. For example, if the evidence for the relationship instance is predicted transcription factor binding based upon sequence similarity between the chromosome and a consensus sequence, the genomic location may record the location of the best match.
FK to Model.NetworkRelContext pointing the specific instance of a network relationship supported by the associated evidence.
When applicable, a p-value associated with this evidence. This may be a value stored elsewhere in the Results schema in this database.
When applicable, a score associated with this evidence. This may be a value stored elsewhere in the Results schema in this database.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm pointing to the type of score associated with score1.
When applicable, a secondary score associated with this evidence. This may be a value stored elsewhere in the Results schema in this database.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm pointing to the type of score associated with score2.

When applicable, textual annotation for the relationship instance. For example, if the evidence for the relationship instance is predicted transcription factor binding based upon sequence similarity between the chromosome and a consensus sequence, text_evidence may store the consensus sequence.

This table links specific instances of network relationships (stored in Model.NetworkRelContext) to the evidence or support for that instance which may be stored elsewhere as an entry in the database and linked via a soft key (fact_table_id, fact_row_id).

FK to Model.NetworkNode to indicate a second network node involved in the network relationship. This attribute is nullable; when left NULL the relationship is interpreted as an association between the network node (pointed to by node_id) and a biological context (stored in Model.ModelContext) linked in a specific instance of the abstract relationship defined via Model.NetworkRelContext.
FK to Model.NetworkNode to indicate a network node involved in the network relationship.
When applicable, a weight or confidence associated with the abstract network relationship.
This table stores abstract associations or relationships that define edges linking one or more network node(s).
Display label for relationships of this type in visualizations of the network.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm that indicates the type of relationship, e.g., binds, activates, expresses, inhibits, required for, etc.

This table provides details about network relationship types to facilitate model visualization by linking types to display labels, as relationships of the same fundametal type (e.g., "is_a", "connects", "binds", "activates") may have model-specific interpretations.
This points to the manufacturer release for this reporter set (e.g. a particular Affymetrix array) as a FK to SRes.ExternalDatabaseRelease.
When applicable, this stores the location of the reporter within the reporter set (e.g. block, row, column coordinates for a apotted microarray, etc.).
This denotes the unique identifier for this reporter from the manufacturer (e.g. a probe set id for an Affymetrix array).

This table stores information about individual reporters in a reporter set (stored in Platform.ReporterSetImp), e.g. if the reporter set is an Affymetrix microarray, this tables stores information about each of its probe sets, if the reporter set is a spotted array, this table stores information about each of its spots.
This table links reporters (stored in Platform.Reporter) to genes (stored in DoTS.gene) represented by those reporters.
When applicable, this table stores the location of reporter sequences in the genome.
This table links reporters (stored in Platform.Reporter) to nucleid acid features (stored in DoTS.NAFeatureImp) represented by those reporters.

If this reporter set is in another repository (e.g. it represents a microarray stored in a public repository like ArrayExpress or GEO), this points to the appropriate release of such a repository (FK to SRes.ExternalDatabaseRelease), else this is to be left null.
FK to SRes.Contact to indicate the manufacturer for this reporter set.
The name of the reporter set, e.g. 'Affymetrix HG_U95A'.
FK to Study.Protocol to indicate the protocol used to assemble this reporter set.

If this is part of a group of reporter sets (e.g. a collection of microarrays which together cover a given set of genes, like the Agilent Human 1 cDNA Microarray), this points to such a group via a FK to Platform.ReporterSetGroup.

If this reporter set is in another repository (e.g. it represents a microarray stored in a public repository like ArrayExpress or GEO), this denotes the unique identifier for this reporter set in such a repository, else this is to be left null.
When applicable, FK to SRes.OntologyTerm to indicate the substrate, e.g. 'glass' for certain microarrays, etc.
When applicable, FK to SRes.OntologyTerm to indicate the type of surface for this reporter set, e.g. 'polylysine'.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm to indicate the type of technology for this reporter set, e.g. 'RT-PCR', 'Serial Analysis', 'in_situ_oligo_features', etc.
When applicable, the version of the reporter set, e.g. for Affymetrix HG_U95A, this could be 'v2'.

This table stores information about sets of reporters such as: microarrays, RT-PCR sets, SAGE tags, etc. It is an Imp table so that appropriate subclass views can be created to this end. For example, if the reporter set is a microarray the numberN attributes can be used to denote number of grid rows, number of grid columns, number of sub rows, number of subcolumns, etc.

This tables is used to store additional annotation about a reporter set if not all can be accomodated in Platform.ReporterSetImp. Annotation is in the free form (name, value), where name indicates the type of annotation (e.g. 'probe_type') and value is the corresponding value (e.g. '36-mer').

This table is used to store groups of reporter sets, e.g. a collection of microarrays which together cover a given set of genes, like the Agilent Human 1 cDNA Microarray. The name and the description for the group can be accomodated in here.

This table stores editing events. Genomic segments can either be indicated by a FK to DoTS.NAFeatureImp or by directly storing in this table a pointer to a sequence (FK to DoTS.NASequenceImp), together with event_start and event_end relative to that sequence.

This table stores results for pairwise comparisons of gene families (e.g. homologenes) between two conditions, e.g. differential expression results or differential binding sites results, etc. The attributes mean1, sd1, mean2, sd2, fdr, fold_change, test_statistic, p_value, adj_p_value, q_value, confidence_up, and confidence-down are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterDiffResult.

This table stores expression results associated to gene families (e.g. homologenes, etc.). The attributes value, confidence, standard_error, and categorical_value are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterExpression.

This table stores results for pairwise comparisons of genes between two conditions, e.g. differential expression results or differential TFBS results, etc. The attributes mean1, sd1, mean2, sd2, fdr, fold_change, test_statistic, p_value, adj_p_value, q_value, confidence_up, and confidence-down are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterDiffResult.

This table stores expression results associated to genes (e.g. derived from their representative reporter expression values in a microarray experiments or from quantification in an RNA-Seq experiment based on a given gene model). The attributes value, confidence, standard_error, and categorical_value are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterExpression.
This table stores similarity measures between pairs of genes from a given protocol application node (analysis).

This table stores results for pairwise comparisons of nucleid acid features between two conditions, e.g. differential expression results or differential TFBS results, etc. The attributes mean1, sd1, mean2, sd2, fdr, fold_change, test_statistic, p_value, adj_p_value, q_value, confidence_up, and confidence-down are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterDiffResult.

This table stores expression results associated to nucleic acid features (e.g. derived from their representative reporter expression values in a microarray experiments or from quantification in an RNA-Seq experiment based on a given gene model). The attributes value, confidence, standard_error, and categorical_value are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterExpression.
When applicable, an adjusted p-value (e.g. for multiple testing) for this reporter's differential behavior between the two conditions.
When applicable, a confidence value for down-regulation of this reporter in one condition as compared to the other.
When applicable, a confidence value for up-regulation of this reporter in one condition as compared to the other.
When applicable, a fdr for this reporter's differential behavior between the two conditions.
When applicable, the fold change for a measurement of interest (e.g. expression) for this reporter between the two conditions.
When applicable, the mean of a measurement of interest (e.g. expression) for this reporter in condition 1.
When applicable, the mean of a measurement of interest (e.g. expression) for this reporter in condition 2.
When applicable, a p-value for this reporter's differential behavior between the two conditions.
Points to the protocol application node (in Study.ProtocolAppNode) representing what yielded these results (e.g. an analysis).
When applicable, a q-value for this reporter's differential behavior between the two conditions.
When applicable, the standard deviation of a measurement of interest (e.g. expression) for this reporter in condition 1.
When applicable, the standard deviation of a measurement of interest (e.g. expression) for this reporter in condition 2.
When applicable, the value of the test stastic used to measure this reporter's differential behavior between the two conditions.
This table stores results for pairwise comparisons of reporters between two conditions, e.g. differential expression results or differential TFBS results, etc.
This can be used to store non-quantitative or semi-quantitative expression values (e.g. present/absent, etc.).
When applicable, this can be used to store a confidence measure for the expression value.
Points to the protocol application node (in Study.ProtocolAppNode) representing what yielded these results (e.g. a quantification, or an analysis, etc.).
When applicable, this can be used to store a standard error for the expression value.
This is the expression value.

This table stores expression results for reporters in a reporter set. These could be raw or processed expression values, depending on the type of protocol application node (e.g. quantification or analysis) that they are coming from.

This table stores results for pairwise comparisons of transcripts between two conditions, e.g. differential expression results or differential TFBS results, etc. The attributes mean1, sd1, mean2, sd2, fdr, fold_change, test_statistic, p_value, adj_p_value, q_value, confidence_up, and confidence-down are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterDiffResult.

This table stores expression results associated to transcrips (e.g. derived from their representative reporter expression values in a microarray experiments or from quantification in an RNA-Seq experiment based on a given gene model). The attributes value, confidence, standard_error, and categorical_value are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterExpression.

This table stores results for pairwise comparisons of genomic segments between two conditions. Genomic segments and their strand can either be indicated by a FK to DoTS.NAFeatureImp or by directly storing in this table a pointer to a sequence (FK to DoTS.NASequenceImp), together with segment_start and segment_end relative to that sequence, as well as strand information (0 if on the + strand, 1 if on the reverse strand). The attributes mean1, sd1, mean2, sd2, fdr, fold_change, test_statistic, p_value, adj_p_value, q_value, confidence_up, and confidence-down are used in the same way as the analogous attributes in Results.ReporterDiffResult.
This can be used to store non-quantitative or semi-quantitative values associated to this result.
When applicable, a confidence associated to this result.
When applicable, a fdr associated to this result.
The genetic location of this segment, when applicable.
When applicable, a p-value associated to this result.
Points to the protocol application node (in Study.ProtocolAppNode) representing what yielded these results (e.g. an analysis).

Can be used to store any kind of score attached to this genomic segment result, such as the coverage if the results represent a coverage plot, or a ratio if the results represent peak calls obtained by comparing to a control, etc.
Additional score holder, to be used as score1.
When applicable, a standard_error associated to this result.

This table stores results that are of the form of genomics segments with possibly associated scores (e.g. coverage plots or peak calls from a High-Throughput-Sequencing experiment). Genomic segments and their strands can either be indicated by a FK to DoTS.NAFeatureImp or by directly storing in this table a pointer to a sequence (FK to DoTS.NASequenceImp), together with segment_start and segment_end relative to that sequence, as well as strand information (0 if on the + strand, 1 if on the reverse strand).
This table stores linkage-disequilibrium results between two loci (SNPs).
Points to the protocol application node (in Study.ProtocolAppNode) representing the analysis that yielded these results.
position of the first SNP; e.g., chr:pos
position of the second SNP; e.g., chr:pos
The ID of the first SNP in the original source from which its definition was taken
The ID of the second SNP in the original source from which its definition was taken
linkage r-squared (r^2) value
normalized coefficient of linkage disequilibrium (D')
log odds of linkage disequilibrium between two loci
any additional score (e.g., p-value, bin)
any additional score (e.g., p-value, bin)
The names of the authors.
FK to Sres.BibRefType. The id of the type of this bibliographic reference.
Primary key.
FK to Contact. The id of the person to contact regarding this reference.
The name of the editor.
The issue number of the journal in which this reference was published.
The medline ID for this reference.
The page numbers of this reference in the journal.
The name of the journal in which this reference was published.
The pubmed ID for this reference.
The title of the reference.
The URI for this reference.
The volume number of the journal in which this reference was published.
The year this reference was published.
Each entry in this table represents a reference to an article, book, or other publication.
Street address of the Contact or Affiliation.
Additional street address information of the Contact or Affiliation.
Pointer to SRes.Conact for the entry containing contact information for the affiliation of the contact.
City used in the mailing address for the Contact or Affiliation.
Primary key.
Country used in the mailing address for the Contact or Affiliation.
Email address of the Contact or Affiliation.
Foreign key to SRES.ExternalDatabaseRelease.
Fax number of the Contact or Affiliation.
First name of the Contact. If Affiliation, leave null.
Last name of the Contact. If Affiliation, leave null.
Complete name (first, middle initial and last name) of the Contact or the name of the Affiliation.
Phone number of the Contact or Affiliation.
the unique identifier of the entry in the external database
State used in the mailing address for the Contact or Affiliation.
Zip code used in the mailing address for the Contact or Affiliation.
Holds contact information (e.g. name, email address, phone number).
Continuation of the comment (if longer than 255 chars)
Primary key column
FK to ExternalDatabase
Primary identification string for the entry
A comment
The secondary identification string for the entry
External reference entries
Special table for Enzyme Classification (EC) numbers organized to aid queries as each number position represents a level of classification.

Holds the name of the resource where datasets, ontology terms, identifiers, pathways, etc. were obtained. Can refer to local resources as external is meant to denote anything besides the GUS instance in which this table resides.
Describes specific version and source location of imported resources.
Associated with NCBI taxon table to describe alternative genetic codes used by some species.

Relationships between ontology terms are captured as a triple of subject, predicate, object as attributes with foreign keys to OntologyTerm. The type of relationship is a foreign key to OntologyRelationshipType.
text descriptor for the entry
Primary key.
Describes the type of relationship formed by the terms in the RDF triple.
Provides synonyms where available for terms in OntologyTerm table.
The unique identifier of the term within the resource (MGED Ontology).
Table for all terms from ontologies (e.g., GO, MO, SO), controlled vocabularies, enumerated lists, etc. except for Taxon and EC numbers.
text description of the entry
text descriptor for the entry
Primary key.
Describes the type of the term (e.g. Class, Individual).
Pathways include metabolic, signaling, and other types imported form sources such as KEGG.
Provides soft links to the table and row describing the node (e.g., entry in Gene table). Also provides helpful information on type and location for visualization.
Foreign key to downstream PathwayNode for directed relationships. If undirected then arbitrary which is node vs associated node.
Foreign key to OntologyTerm table for type of edge (relationship) between nodes.

Linkages (edges) between pathway entities (nodes) such as proteins, metabolites, genes, etc. typically imported an external database such as KEGG. Node and associated node are specified in the PathwayNode table.
Phenotypes are defined in the PATO ontology stored in OntologyTerm and associated with anatomy, cells, and developmental stage specified with foreign keys to OntologyTerm.
Foreign key to SRes.GeneticCode
Foreign key to SRes.GeneticCode, refers to mitochondrial genome
Primary taxon identifier used by NCBI.
Pointer to SRes.Taxon.
Scientific classification category e.g.species, genus, kindom, etc.
Primary key.
Holds information from the NCBI Taxonomy.
text descriptor for the entry
Type of name e.g. scientific name, synonym, mispelling
Foreign key to SRes.Taxon.
Primary key.
The unique variant of this name if name not unique
Holds information about the name of the taxon referred to by the taxon_id.
We're going to drop this column

This table attaches annotation to protocol application nodes. For example, if the node is a biomaterial, annotations such as cell type, strain or line, developmental stage can be stored using this table and pointing to relevant entries in SRes.OntologyTerm. If the protocol application node instead yields a dataset (e.g. the node type is a quantification, analysis, etc.) the FK to Core.TableInfo can be used to indicate which table in the database stores the dataset itself (e.g. Results.GeneExpression).
This table lists grants and points to their main contacts (stored in SRes.Contact).
Links inputs (stored in Study.ProtocolAppNode) to protocol applications (stored in Study.ProtocolApp).
Links oututs (stored in Study.ProtocolAppNode) to protocol applications (stored in Study.ProtocolApp).
If this protocol is described in a publication or other reference this attribute points to it, as a FK to SRes.BibliographicReference.

If the protocol is in another repository (e.g. a public repository like ArrayExpress or GEO), this points to the appropriate release of such a repository (FK to SRes.ExternalDatabaseRelease), else this is to be left null.
FK to SRes.OntologyTerm which points to the type of protocols, e.g. hybridization, labeling, feature_extraction, etc.
If the protocol is in another repository (e.g. a public repository like ArrayExpress or GEO), this denotes the unique identifier for this protocol in such a repository, else this is to be left null.
When applicable, a Uniform Resource Identifier for this protocol. For example, to denote the location of a file with the protocol information.
This table stores protocols, experimental or computational.
Stores particular applications of protocol series.
Points to the operator (FK to SRes.Contact) for the order_num-th protocol in the series.
The order_num of the protocol in the protocol application which was carried out by this operator.
Stores the operators for each of the protocols in a protocol application.

If the node corresponds to an entity present in another repository (e.g. an assay in GEO), this points to the appropriate release of such a repository (FK to SRes.ExternalDatabaseRelease), else this is to be left null.
If the node corresponds to an entity present in another repository (e.g. an assay in GEO), this denotes the unique identifier for this entity in such a repository, else this is to be left null.
Points to the taxon associated to this node (FK to SRes.Taxon).
This points to the type of protocol application node e.g.: biosource, biosample, labeled extract, assay, acquisition, quantification, analysis, etc. It is a FK to SRes.OntologyTerm.

When applicable, a Uniform Resource Identifier for this node. For example, if the node represents an acquisition, this could provide the location for the associated image file; if the node represents a quantification, this could provide the location for the associated raw data file, etc.
This table stores the entities that represent nodes of the experimental diagram for a study. These entities are inputs and/or outputs of applications of experimental or computational protocols.
For a parameter whose value corresponds to an entry in this database, indicates the primary key of that entry in the table pointed to by Study.ProtocolApp.Param.table_id.
For a parameter whose value corresponds to an entry in this database, indicates the table containing that entry.

This table stores the values of a given protocol parameter in a protocol application. Different attributes corresponding to different value data types can be used or one can point to an entry in the database with the soft key (table_id, row_id).
Points to the data type for the parameter, e.g. string, integer, etc., as stored in SRes.OntologyTerm.
The default value for this parameter, if any.
Set to 1 if this parameter can be set by the user, set to 0 if it is computed and set automatically.
The parameter name, e.g. 'amount amplified', or 'software version'.
When applicable points to the units of measurement for the parameter values, e.g. microgram, meter, etc. as stored in SRes.OntologyTerm.

This table stores the parameters that apply to a protocol (stored in Study.Protocol), both those that a user can set when running the protocol and those whose (optimal) values are determined and set automatically during the application of the protocol.

A collection of one or more protocols applied serially. Sometimes, when multiple protocols are serially applied, not all intermediate inputs/outputs need to be stored Study.ProtocolAppNode. In this case it is useful to group those protocols into a series.
The order of this protocol in the protocol series.
Links protocol series (stored in Study.ProtocolSeries) to the protocols (stored in Study.Protocol) that comprise them, in order.

If the study is in another repository (e.g. a public repository like ArrayExpress or GEO), this points to the appropriate release of such a repository (FK to SRes.ExternalDatabaseRelease), else this is to be left null.
If the study is part of an investigation, this points to the investigation (FK to Study.Study), else this is to be left null.
If the study is in another repository (e.g. a public repository like ArrayExpress or GEO), this denotes the unique identifier for this study in such a repository, else this is to be left null.
This table stores information about studies or investigations (an investigation is a collection of studies). This includes a name (or title), description, goal, approaches, results and conclusions.
This table links studies/investigations (stored in Study.Study) to all relevant bibliographic references (stored in SRes.BibliographifReference).
This points to the role (e.g. submitter) of a given contact in a study/investigation, FK to SRes.OntologyTerm.
This table links studies/investigations (stored in Study.Study) to all relevant contacts (stored in SRes.Contact).
This table lists all design types (FK to SRes.OntologyTerm) that are applicable to a study/investigation (stored in Study.Study).
This attribute points to the type of the study factor as stored in SRes.OntologyTerm.

This table lists all factors/covariates of interest in a study (stored in Study.Study). For example a study might comprise assays that involve samples from different tissues, in which case tissue would typically be a factor of interest.

When the value of a study factor at a protocol application node corresponds to an entry in this database, this points to the entry in the relevant table. For example, if the protocol application node is a microarray assay and the array used is a value of interest, this can point the entry in Platform.ReporterSetImp corresponding that array.

When the value of a study factor at a protocol application node corresponds to an entry in this database, this points to the table (FK to Core.TableInfo) storing that entry. For example, if the protocol application node is a microarray assay and the array used is a value of interest, this can point to the Platform.ReporterSetImp table.
Stores the value of the study factor at this protocol application node.

This table links study factors (stored in Study.StudyFactor) to protocol application nodes (stored in Study.ProtocolAppNode), providing the value of the factor for that node. For example if the factor is tissue and a protocol application node is a biomaterial such as a liver sample, liver is the value of this factor for that node. One has the option to associate the value of a factor only to the first node in the graph to which it applies, or to associate it also to all subsequent nodes.
This table links studies/investigations (stored in Study.Study) to fundings (stored in Study.Funding).
This table links studies/investigations (stored in Study.Study) to protocol application nodes (stored in Study.ProtocolAppNode).
